This documentary was not just meant to inform the people; it was a warning a warning that the sins of the past would come back to haunt the Filipino people, and they have. In recent months, the Philippines has been marred by controversies involving ghost projects and corrupt officials. Yet, after speaking with many people about this matter, one question always prevails: How? How did the corruption, plunder, and blatant theft from the Filipino people become so severe?Upon watching this, the answer became clear as day: it is because we allowed those who started the problem to get away with it. We, as Filipinos, glorified the rich and powerful, while the poor who fought back were treated as criminals. The rich became gods, the supposed benefactors of the poor, when in truth, what they gave was only a fraction of what they had stolen. The Marcoses became the blueprint of Philippine corruption today. They set the rules on how to plunder the people. To fix this issue, we must first hold accountable those who began it in the first place.Democracy no longer truly exists in the Philippines, for it has long been the government against the people ever since the Marcoses were allowed back into the political landscape. Forgetting the past horrors, terrors, and sins has only allowed history to repeat itself. It may not always be under the same name or family, but it is carried out in the same way. If we want change, we must believe that it is not a question of when but of how. We must commit to a long-term process of change, not fall for empty promises. A nation cannot be built in a day, and solutions to systemic issues will never materialize in just a few years.Despite all this, I remain optimistic that these recent issues of corruption will open the eyes of those who were once blinded by words and false promises. The Filipino people should no longer be bound by biased perceptions; we are slowly beginning to see the truth. We are being played and I hope these events will finally serve as the catalyst for change: a change in governance, a change in mentality, and a change for the betterment of the Philippines.

"Now is what's important, so the past is past. There are so many things in the past that we should forget. In fact, it's no longer there."The first time I saw this documentary was in early-2020. I was in the living room with my parents, my tita and my lola; they were all alive during Martial Law. I recall how annoyed my family were as Imelda talked about her side of the story and how "sad" it was to see the country turn their backs on the Marcoses. Even then, perhaps due in part to my family's influence, I was heavily critical of the Marcoses and their claims, as well as the rhetoric of then-president Rodrigo Duterte.This was months before the pandemic that was poorly addressed by Duterte's administration, three years before Bongbong would be elected straight to the presidential seat, and six years before Duterte would be charged with crimes against humanity by the ICC and sent to the Hague while his followers claimed that he was "unjustly arrested".I love the way that this documentary was shot. The juxtaposition of the lavish Marcos spendings with the effects they have had on the lowest sectors of society do a good job at providing insight into the sheer amount of ill-gotten wealth they have procured over the years. The intimate interviews we get from this documentary are also a huge highlight for me. It makes me wonder how the crew were able to get so many high-profile people for this documentary.In retrospect, it is almost horrible foreshadowing to see all this talk of BBM's race to vice presidency when he is currently our president. It's like he got what he wanted and more. What does it say about us as a country that we are willing to let the son of a dictator and kleptocrat, as well as their family, back into power? Or rather, what does it say about our education systems and efforts to retain the facts of the Martial Law era?To still see the Marcos family in power shows that they really did essentially get away almost scot-free. At this point in time, it is more imperative than ever to never forget what their dynasty has done to our country, and to never again repeat the mistakes of the past. i've watched this too many times but the initial feeling has never left. it's one thing to have a white director try to spell out the bloody history of a country she's never known, it's another to give Imelda the platform and attention she's always had in abundance but still seem to feel like she lacks. which is pretty much appropriate considering her insatiable desire not only for attention, but also power and glory.but i guess only a white director could have ever stepped foot in their mansion, could have used her prestige and privilege to make the interview feel like flattery despite it being a portrait of a murderous family, could have gotten the funding to even make this possible.i am torn between two things: on the one hand, my background in Psychology has me looking at everything as a case study, and what is more interesting than a powerful family who built their fortune and influence on violence? I generally try to approach documentaries with some degree of neutrality. But how can you do that with Imelda Marcos? In her introduction, she seems like a silly, unassuming old lady sitting in her gilded home and her many shoes, handing out pesos to street children with an air of supreme disinterest. Lauren Greenfield paints a complex portrait, peeling back the layers to reveal a dangerous, intelligent and manipulative figure. Greenfield and her editor keep the film's pulse steady, combatting each of Imelda's increasingly ridiculous lies with evidence to the contrary without feeling sequential. I couldn't believe my ears when she said that martial law was the best time for human rights. I found it difficult to watch. Maybe that's because of my personal histories. Watching Ferdinand Marcos' body be interred at Libingan ng mga Bayani, where my grandfather is buried, left a pit in my stomach. Hearing the testimonies of anti-Marcos activists was devastating. And knowing that I have relatives, including my mother, who remain vocal loyalists and direct victims of the disinformation and whitewashing campaigns that are at the center of this film was another gut punch.The film was completed in 2019 and leaves off on Leni Robredo's victory over BBM in the VP election. It seems that democracy prevailed, and presents like a cautionary tale of the Marcoses; of what can be done when political dynasties are left unchecked with power and influence. As if Greenfield is wagging her finger saying, "don't do what the Filipinos did!" But listening to BBM ramble about stolen elections a full four years before Trump sent a chill down my spine. The propaganda and historical revisionism. The cult of personality. The militarization of the police. It's extra-haunting to see this in 2024, knowing that my family's motherland is under the thumb of the Marcoses again.Well-made, prescient and powerful.

As a social studies teacher, I help students sharpen their critical thinking skills by presenting them facts and figures to guide them in forming their own conclusions. I don't infiltrate to them my own viewpoints, for it may influence their own views. I want my students to form their own opinions and make sure that they are based on facts and empirical evidence. This is exactly how Lauren Greenfield's The Kingmaker presented one of history's most divisive topic. It is a documentary where you see the camera roll and witness the actions speak for themselves. There is no narration, no reenactments, no script, and no talking heads. The main subjects themselves, the Marcos Family (mostly Imelda Marcos) are the ones narrating the entire story. The camera is basically a fly on the wall. Real footages and records from the exact events are also shown. I've also read that the intended direction of the film depends on how interviews went. This means the film does not intentionally gear towards one side of the story only, as both the Marcoses side, the victims, and the witnesses were evenly presented. The result? A compelling story of a true event that almost feels like fiction due to its shocking and unbelievable accounts. It makes you wonder why the Marcoses agree to be the subject of this documentary and how they feel about this.This educational documentary might be a hard watch for some, and I highly advice that the best way to watch this is to have an open mind, without any pre-conceived notions about what the show is about. "Perception is real, and the truth is not."One of the first images that come to mind when watching this film is simply of an old woman, clad in Filipino dress, in a gilded room, adorned with paintings by Picasso and Monet, with golden idols strewn across the tables and in a room that harkens back to kings and queens of old, as she tells her story about how bad she had it. It's a lie, of course, as most things that the Marcos family has, have and will say, but it's a lie people believe. Imelda Marcos understands the power the media has, the way she contorts and changes her words to fit the narrative she wants us to believe, but the editing doesn't allow her words to come out unscathed, juxtaposing her picturesque words with words and footage of torture, punishment and other such catastrophes that could make even the most sympathetic follower squirm. But it's not enough.Of course, it's easy to say that putting her in front of the camera is a good or bad idea, but we often forget that words don't exist on their own in film, they come from the interaction between shots, and even the relationship between footage and audio, and placing neutrality and restraint against an obviously inhumane person is immoral. Covering someone like Imelda Marcos, a person who has almost complete control and understanding over her image is tricky to make well, especially as an outsider like Greenfield, but if you want to cover Marcos, and all of their infamy, especially the person who essentially serves, and still does, as right hand man of her family, you have to be unrelenting and unflinching. As the Philippines evolves, technology moves forward, and the way we consume and the way we determine what is just and true gets harder everyday. It is imperative we are aware of this as our history becomes rewritten, crimes of the past become null and dynasties rise back to power. We have to be aware of these things, these ideas that media can be manipulated and used as propaganda, as agents of control because all media exists that way.Triumph of the Will, a 1935 film depicting Hitler and his Third Reich, is notorious for shaping the way we view the Nazi Party, less as an army breaking apart at the seams as they slaughtered one another due to paranoia, and more of an unrelenting force set out to destroy all we know and love. This disconnect from reality and fiction led to our newfound perception of these people, and it is happening to us.By simply giving these people a platform, by giving them full reign on how they are covered, how they are broadcast nationally, we are giving them the power to manipulate, and it is happening all over, as seen within the film. That's why, when we come to critique this family, we have to take them swiftly and dangerously, not leaving shallow cuts, but scathing stab wounds. Ferdinand Marcos is not a hero, he was a fascist. Plain and simple. He embezzled government funds, he tortured, killed and violated his people and he left wounds we are still covering from, and this revisionist history we have now, the way even the lower classes, who were hit hardest, still believe that crimes are to be ignored in favor of worshipping a past that never existed is something to be concerned about.These crimes were never reconciled with, they have no closure and they are still open to this very day. The animals Imelda Marcos released upon Calauit are still hanging there, the stolen jewelry she has is still not returned, and the system that these people manipulated and used is still not fixed, as seen by the blood on our streets and cries in the middle of the night, with politicians who believe that blood of the poor spilled by corrupt cops is valid.The people have every right to be angry, but we should be critical and understand our history, especially after the current context of the son of the late dictator, Ferdinand Marcos Jr., bearing the name of his father, has won the election, along with Rodrigo Duterte's daughter, who has killed people in the name of his "drug war." We have a history of revolutions, some won and some lost, and the fight for liberty doesn't stop when someone wins or loses. It is won through continued and watchful progress, through knowledge and the acknowledgement of the past and through wisdom to see through the lies. Anger is in our blood, use it wisely.

The Kingmaker is the story of ruthless and narcissistic Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, and her family‚Äôs attempts to work their way back into power after her husband‚Äôs overthrow.Imelda was the wife of the corrupt Ferdinand Marcos, who ruled the country between 1965-1986. In interviews she comes across as caring, generous, and eccentric, but the documentary reveals the more sinister aspects of her and her husband's rule; in particular the theft of billions from the country and a period of brutal dictatorship involving torture, rape and murder.During martial law in the Philippines over 3,000 people were killed and 70,000 imprisoned, some for as little as being at a meeting with five or more people. Activists appear in the film with chilling stories of being tortured and sexually assaulted under the Marcos regime. The reign of terror lasted until Ferdinand was overthrown after trying to rig an election in 1986, ushering in democracy in the country over the protests of some of America‚Äôs Cold War hawks.It‚Äôs never clear how involved Imelda was in the worst acts of her husband‚Äôs government, although there are hints in the film that she helped to mastermind the assassination of an opposition leader. It is obvious that she benefitted from the record-breaking corruption of the Marcos regime; as a result her habit of handing out wads of money to the poor takes on a sinister air.If there is one word to sum up Imelda, it is narcissistic. Throughout the documentary her hunger for popularity goes beyond all reason; she sees nothing wrong with importing giraffes and zebras into a country where there are no vets to take care of them, leaving them suffering from skin diseases. At one point, she seemingly sincerely says that Chairman Mao told her that she could end the Cold War.Her accumulation of wealth goes beyond practical levels and seems compulsive; her family looted a literally record-breaking amount of money and helped to impoverish The Philippines for decades, and on a more petty level she was famous for having a collection of over 3,000 shoes. You could say that Imelda is similar to Trump, or alternatively, that Trump resembles any number of self-deluded dictators throughout history, who tend to be self-obsessed in the worst way.Such characters have an enduring appeal despite their ridiculousness, and as many people in the documentary note, the Philippines has been forgiving to strongmen in the past. With Rodrigo Duterte's brutal rule coming to an end and Imelda's son Bongbong Marcos in power in the Philippines as of May 2022, the country may unfortunately be on a path to repeating its previous mistakes.
